subjectData.thoughts: I think it is difficult to decide between maximizing the benefit as a whole group versus maximizing the benefit of each individual. But in the case of health care and food, I think it is only fair to think from the perspective of each individual. People that live far away are most likely less advantaged people who need the meal the most. And the people who need the respirator the longest are people who are the most vulnerable populations such as kids and elderlies. We all need assistance and help from others and there will be the time that we are group 4. So when we have the power to decide how to allocate resources, it is important to remember that we all at least once had received help from others or had depended on others. So when making the decision, it is important to look at the big pictures, but also we should keep in mind the minority individuals and their needs.
subjectData.strategies: I slide the bar to the leftmost to see the best average. Then I slowly slide to the right, to make sure the minority group has at least half the number of the group above it while keeping the average relatively unaffected; However, in the case of the respirator and meal scenarios, I might have given the minority group more weight while in the corporate context I consider the general picture as the priority. In the prison scenario, I am not sure which group is the “more dangerous” group, so I choose the option that will make each group similar in number while in some cases there is a gradual but slight decrease of numbers from groups 1 to 4.
subjectData.userAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/80.0.3987.163 Safari/537.36

trials.prompt: A bank must decide who to give home loans to. Only 10% of the loans can default and some groups are more likely to default than others, so giving loans to some people may result in less loans for others. How should the loans be allocated?

A local newspaper company is trying to decide how to divide up the paper routes. Some groups of delivery people are faster than others, and if too many papers don't get delivered, customers get angry. Giving more to one delivery group may mean less for others. The icons below show how many routes are given to each group. How should they divide up the routes?

Meals on Wheels is tasked with delivering meals to homebound persons. Their time and resources are limited, and some groups live further away, so delivering to some groups may mean less deliveries to others. The numbers below represent how many meals are given to each group. How should they allocate their time for deliveries?

A corporate recruiter is seeking to fill a position at their company. They have limited recruiting budget, and each group uses different job search services, each with different success rates at delivering qualified applicants. The values below show the number of applicants in each group for a fixed advertising budget. How should they allocate their advertising dollars?

A local hospital has a shortage of respirators for patients during the COVID-19 outbreak. Some patients are more likely to be on respirators for longer than others, so less patients will be able to use one. The numbers below represent the number of patients receiving respirators. How should the hospital allocate their respirators?

A corporate recruiter is seeking to fill a position at their company. They have limited recruiting budget, and each group uses different job search services, each with different success rates at delivering qualified applicants. The values below show the number of applicants in each group for a fixed advertising budget. How should they allocate their advertising dollars?

A local newspaper company is trying to decide how to divide up the paper routes. Some groups of delivery people are faster than others, and if too many papers don't get delivered, customers get angry. Giving more to one delivery group may mean less for others. The icons below show how many routes are given to each group. How should they divide up the routes?

A local hospital has a shortage of respirators for patients during the COVID-19 outbreak. Some patients are more likely to be on respirators for longer than others, so less patients will be able to use one. The numbers below represent the number of patients receiving respirators.
